title: WeThePe0ple
author: WeThePe0ple
content: I just read that investing about $200 000 in real estate in Dubai, qualifies people for citizenship.My crypto portfolio is not worth $200 000 yet but I believe it will definitely get there one day in the next 10 years.Tax rules in my country are not clear but our IRS has a bad reputation and I do not intend to ever cash out my crypto holdings to any regular bank in Europe.I prefer that my government has no idea that I even hold crypto. Cashing out here will immediately flag the IRS to check out all my earnings, also the work related ones. The IRS never leaves anyones home without a serious tax bill. In my neighboring country Holland, citizens already have to declare crypto holdings (even unrealized gains) so that the government can tax people just for holding BTC. This is theft. I only intend to cash out crypto profits in countries that have 0% crypto tax and a proven track record of this. They also have to have a reputation of not sharing financial information (property, account balances..) with other countries. For now I think that only Dubai has this, but I believe that Donald Trump is capable of doing this in the USA as well.If anyone has experience in Dubai, please share this.If other countries are good for this, please share. I also want to know what it takes to stop being a resident for tax purposes in your own country.Maybe I have to give up my nationality for this? One of my ideas is to rent out my property in Europe, move to a low cost nation (I like South America) and live from the rental income there. I can invest in crypto on the side. But if I remain a tax resident in my country, I am still obligated to declare all assets and properties in other countries too.

comments.author: bad23
comments.body: There are two things in life that are sure. "Death and taxes' No one likes to pay taxes but be happy that knowing that when you are taxed that means you are making money. If you are willing to leave your country to avoid paying your tax,  I would say you don't have a very good country.

comments.author: NeuroticFish
comments.body: Quote from: WeThePe0ple on March 02, 2025, 01:14:40 PMOne of my ideas is to rent out my property in Europe, move to a low cost nation (I like South America) and live from the rental income there.It depends on many factors. e.g. in "cheaper" countries you will not have proper medical care and overall services, you will face corruption (i.e. a lot of hidden costs), if you have family then there's a good change the schools are not great. For some this is a problem, for others it's not. Keep in mind that living in a country is significantly different than doing one week of holiday there.Quote from: WeThePe0ple on March 02, 2025, 01:14:40 PMIf anyone has experience in Dubai, please share this.I feared to even visit Dubai, knowing that human rights are a bad topic there and knowing that normal things in Europe can be an issue in the Islamic states. And while there is a tad of understanding for tourists, there may not be the same for citizens.So it's quite a step and I advise you think it through very good.

comments.author: Fiatless
comments.body: Investing $200k in real estate in Dubai just because you want to avoid crypto tax is not ideal. Except you have a large crypto hodling I don't think it will be profitable. Except if you want to use the citizenship for other purposes or have plans for the property, I don't think it is advisable. Do you really need citizenship to cash out crypto transactions in other countries? If you are considering moving to another country permanently to avoid tax you need to have a rethink. Have you considered your work, security, and family? There are other ways to avoid tax, just seek the advice of a professional. I can only move to a country that is better than my country to avoid taxes.

comments.author: Ziskinberg
comments.body: For individuals, crypto is tax-free, but if you're running a business dealing with crypto, taxes apply once you hit the threshold. So, if your goal is to avoid paying taxes on crypto, moving could be a smart decision especially since capital gains tax can go as high as 15% or even more depending on what country you are living. If your portfolio is large enough that taxes feel like a constant drain on your earnings, then it makes sense to go with whatever helps you maximize your income.For now, there’s no tax, but there’s no guarantee it will stay that way in the future. That’s something worth considering as well.

comments.author: Don Pedro Dinero
comments.body: So, what are you going to do when your portfolio reaches $200,000? Sell it to buy a house there and end up with nothing? How are you going to make a living?  Another thing you're not considering, apart from what NeuroticFish has already mentioned, is that although Dubai is crypto-friendly, it’s not a free-for-all. A couple of months ago, I watched a video on the topic, and Dubai’s banks want you to clearly prove that your funds have a legal origin. So, if your Bitcoin has gone through mixers, for example, you can forget about it.

comments.author: hugeblack
comments.body: You cannot get Citizenship by investing $ 200 000 in Real Estate in Dubai, you can get 2-year UAE Resident visa by investing this amount in real estate and you will get a good return or Ten-Year Golden Visa by Investing A Minimum of 500K.Most of those who come to Dubai are looking for an opportunity to increase their investments. As for taxes, there is no income tax, but the cost of living is relatively high and there is a Value-added tax, VAT.

comments.author: Free Market Capitalist
comments.body: I see more holes in this plan than in a wheel of Swiss cheese.For starters, forget about reaching $200K and moving to Dubai, that’s way too little. That’s just the minimum where you can start seriously considering the idea.And as for moving to South America, I hope you choose wisely because there are too many places where life is worth nothing, and a foreigner is an easy target. Living off your rental income is another plan that looks good on paper but is likely to fail. A property can't be managed remotely, you have to be on top of it. And if you hand it over to an agency to rent out, your profitability will take a significant hit.

comments.author: pinggoki
comments.body: To everyone, don't do what OP says, there's probably more ways to avoid crypto taxes legally and in a much cheaper way. Dubai is so expensive and there's literally a lot of countries out there that's probably going to welcome foreign investments that have a more cheaper purchasing power and you dollar to local currency ratio is so high. Unless you're a big business that wants to make sure that you're getting all the profits for yourself then by all means go to Dubai but if you're not that in that sector, you can probably get by with just a P2P trading, probably much easier for you and you don't have to invest a lot money for preparations.

comments.author: avikz
comments.body: It is a great idea to avoid tax. But ask yourself question - are you ready to give up your own country just to save some taxes? If you are talking about millions and billions, then it still makes sense, but not for something worth less than 200,000. Dubai is a great city. I have been there once and I loved every bit of it. But the cost of leaving is really high compared to many cities in US. So you need to think if you are able to afford the lifestyle of Dubai. It is definitely a tax heaven. But think twice before taking citizenship.
